{{Infobox organization | key_people = [[Sue Gardner]], Executive Director
[[Julia Angwin]] and [[Jeff Larson (journalist)|Jeff Larson]], Founders | footnotes = | name = The Markup | founded_date = {{start date and age|2019}} | founder = | location = [[Manhattan]] | origins = | area_served = [[United States]] | focus = [[Investigative journalism]], [[technology]] | method = | revenue = | endowment = | num_volunteers = | num_members = | owner = | Non-profit_slogan = | homepage = {{url|themarkup.org}} | dissolved = }}'''''The Markup''''' is an American [[nonprofit organization]] based in [[New York City]] that will focus on [[Data-driven journalism|data driven journalism]] covering the ethics and impact of technology on society. Markup was co-founded by two former [[ProPublica]] journalists [[Julia Angwin]] and [[Jeff Larson (journalist)|Jeff Larson]]. The idea was conceived in April 2018, and expects to launch in early 2019.{{Cite news|url=http://www.niemanlab.org/2018/04/former-propublica-journalists-are-launching-a-newsroom-to-cover-the-impact-of-technology-on-society/|title=Former ProPublica journalists are launching a newsroom to cover the impact of technology on society|last=Owen|first=Laura H.|date=2018-04-12|work=Nieman Lab|access-date=2018-09-23}} Like ProPublica, all of their content will be licensed under a [[Creative Commons license]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/09/23/business/media/the-markup-craig-newmark.html|title=News Site to Investigate Big Tech, Helped by Craigslist Founder|last=Bowles|first=Nellie|date=2018-09-23|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en}} == Data journalism == According to Julia Angwin, The Markup plans to collect and create public data sets through [[Freedom of Information Act (United States)|public records]] requests, automated data collection, crowdsourcing of information and creation of tools, for example at ProPublica they built a browser extension to analyze [[Facebook]] ads.{{Cite news|url=https://www.recode.net/2018/9/27/17908798/julia-angwin-markup-jeff-larson-craig-newmark-data-investigative-journalism-peter-kafka-podcast|title=It may be ‘data journalism,’ but Julia Angwin’s new site the Markup is nothing like FiveThirtyEight|work=Recode|access-date=2018-10-01}} == Funding == The Markup received $20 million gift from [[Craigslist]] founder [[Craig Newmark]]. They also raised $2 million from the [[John S. and James L. Knight Foundation|Knight Foundation]] and an additional $1 million from [[Ford Foundation]], [[MacArthur Foundation]] and the Ethics and Governance of Artificial Intelligence Initiative. ==Sources== [[Category:Stub-Class AfC articles]] [[Category:News]] [[Category:Technology websites]] [[Category:Media in New York City]] [[Category:American news websites]] {{nonprofit-org-stub}} {{journalism-stub}}

{{Distinguish|The Sound of Music Live (2015)}} {{Infobox television | show_name = The Sound of Music Live! | image = [[File:Sound of Music Live! logo.png|250px]] | caption = Promotional poster | show_name_2 = | genre = [[Musical theatre|Musical]] [[drama]] | creator = {{Plainlist| * [[Craig Zadan]] * [[Neil Meron]]}} | based_on = ''[[The Sound of Music]]''
by [[Howard Lindsay]]
[[Russel Crouse]] | developer = | writer = Austin Winsberg | director = {{Plainlist| * [[Rob Ashford]] * [[Beth McCarthy-Miller]]}} | creative_director = | presenter = [[NBC]] | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Carrie Underwood]] * [[Stephen Moyer]] * [[Audra McDonald]] * [[Laura Benanti]] * [[Christian Borle]] }} | composer = [[Rodgers and Hammerstein]] | country = United States | language = English | executive_producer = {{Plainlist| * Craig Zadan * Neil Meron}} | producer = Priscilla Taussig | editor = | location = [[Grumman Studios]]
[[Bethpage, New York]] | cinematography = | camera = | runtime = 135 minutes{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Sound-Music-Live-Carrie-Underwood/dp/B00FWMVVLS|title=The Sound of Music Live!: Movies & TV|accessdate=June 16, 2014}} | company = | distributor = [[Universal Studios Home Entertainment]] | picture_format = Color, [[NTSC]], Widescreen | audio_format = Dolby Digital 5.1 | first_aired = {{Start date|2013|12|05}} | followed_by = ''[[Peter Pan Live!]]'' | website = http://www.nbc.com/sound-of-music/ | website_title = ''The Sound of Music Live!'' | production_website = | channel = [[NBC]] }} '''''The Sound of Music Live!''''' is a [[television special]] that was originally broadcast by NBC on December 5, 2013. Produced by [[Craig Zadan]] and [[Neil Meron]], the special was an adaptation of [[Rodgers and Hammerstein]]'s Broadway musical ''[[The Sound of Music]]''. The television special starred [[country music|country]] singer and ''[[American Idol]]'' winner [[Carrie Underwood]] as [[Maria von Trapp]], and was performed and televised [[live television|live]] from [[Grumman Studios]] in [[Bethpage, New York]]. Spearheaded by NBC chairman [[Robert Greenblatt|Bob Greenblatt]], the network positioned the special as being a live [[event television|television "event"]]. In preparing for the broadcast, Meron and Zadan emphasized the logistical challenges that they would face due to the live aspects of the special, and the fact that ''The Sound of Music Live!'' was an adaptation based on the musical itself and not the [[The Sound of Music (film)|1965 film version]]. Meron felt that if the telecast were successful, the concept could become "another kind of entertainment that can exist on TV." By her request, Underwood's casting as Maria was personally endorsed by [[Julie Andrews]], who starred in the 1965 film. The production was met with mixed reviews; much of its criticism was directed towards the casting of Carrie Underwood to play Maria, whom critics (including the real-life [[von Trapp family]]) believed was not experienced enough in theatre to portray such an iconic role. While her vocal performance was praised, her acting was described by critics as "amateur", "lifeless" and lacking emotion. The production was a ratings success for NBC; with a total of 18.62 million live viewers, ''The Sound of Music Live!'' brought the network its highest Thursday night viewership for an entertainment program since the [[Goodnight, Seattle|series finale]] of ''[[Frasier (TV series)|Frasier]]'' in 2004, and prompted NBC to sign Zadan and Meron on to produce more live musicals for the network in the future. ==Plot== Maria Rainer, a [[postulant]] at [[Nonnberg Abbey]] in [[Salzburg]], is contemplating the day she has spent in the mountains ("The Sound of Music"). When she returns to the Abbey, she learns from the Mother Abbess that she is to be the new governess for the von Trappe children. Before she leaves the Abbey, Mother Abbess asks her to teach her the song that she's always singing ("My Favorite Things"). When Maria arrives at the von Trappe house, she is greeted coldly by the Captain and introduced to the children, who enter with military precision. Maria finds that the Captain has emotionally closed himself off since the death of his wife and decides to teach his children the basics of singing to gain their trust and acceptance. A month, later the captain returns home with Elsa Schraeder, whom he is courting, and their friend Max Detweiler, who is looking for the perfect local singing group to perform at the annual Kaltzberg Festival. When his children arrive dressed in clothes Maria had made from her old bedroom curtains he is outraged and embarrassed. Maria then confronts him and tells him how he does not know or understand his children and that they need him but this only upsets him more and he orders her to return to Nonnberg Abbey. However, upon hearing his children sing to Schraeder, his eyes are open to the truth Maria had been speaking and he embraces his children and ask Maria to stay on as governess. He then throws a grand party for Schraeder and when the band plays the [[Ländler]], the captain's youngest son asks Maria to teach him the dance and the captain steps in to help. As the two dance an unspoken attraction begins to arise in the two and Maria puts a stop to the dancing. However, this unspoken attraction did not go unnoticed by Brigitta who confronts Maria on this. Though Maria strongly denies it she begins to realize that Brigitta is telling the truth. Then, Schraeder calls the children out to say good night to the guests and Max is instantly smitten with the idea to have the children sing in the festival and during all the hustle and bustle Maria sneaks off unnoticed and returns to the Abbey, where she confides in the Mother Abbess that she has fallen in love with the captain but that she is ready to take the orders of [[poverty, obedience and chastity]]. The Mother Abbess denies her this and encourages her to take face her problem head-on and to find the life she was born to live. Maria then returns to the von Trapp home and is warmly greeted by the children, who no longer feel the joys of singing due to her sudden departure. When she finds out that the captain intends to marry Schraeder she decides to see her duties through until arrangements can be made for a new governess. However, the political differences between Schraeder and the captain cause the two to realize that they have no future together and she leaves. Meanwhile, the captain confronts Maria and the two admit their feelings for each other. The two agree to marry at the Abbey and while the two are on honeymoon, [[Anschluss|Germany invades Austria]]. When they return, the captain is ordered to accept a commission in the German Navy and report immediately to [[Bremerhaven]]. Maria, thinking quickly, hands the Admiral the program for the Kaltzberg Festival showing that the von Trapp Family Singers are scheduled to perform, so the captain couldn’t possibly leave right away. They are granted permission to perform. During the finale, Max announces that a guard of honor is waiting to escort the captain away as soon as the concert is over. Maria leads the family in one more song to which they escape to one by one and flee to the Abbey. The Nazi soldiers search the Abbey for the von Trapps to no avail, as the family decides to flee Austria over the mountains with Maria's help.{{cite web|url=http://www.masterworksbroadway.com/music/the-sound-of-music-%E2%80%93-music-from-the-nbc-television-event-2013|title=The Sound of Music – Music from the NBC Television Event 2013|work=[[Masterworks Broadway]]|publisher=[[Sony Music Entertainment]]|accessdate=2014-05-19}} ==Cast and crew== :''Cast list adapted from the [[liner notes]] of the soundtrack.''{{cite AV media notes|title=[[The Sound of Music: Music from the NBC Television Event]]|type=[[Compact disc]] [[liner notes]]|year=2013|publisher=[[Sony Masterworks|Masterworks]]|page=3|id=88843 79814 2}} [[File:Carrie Underwood 2, 2012.jpg|thumb|upright|Carrie Underwood in 2012]] [[File:Stephen Moyer cropped.jpg|thumb|upright|Stephen Moyer]] ;Main {{Div col}} * [[Carrie Underwood]] as [[Maria von Trapp]] (née Rainer) * [[Stephen Moyer]] as [[Georg von Trapp|Captain Georg von Trapp]] * [[Audra McDonald]] as [[Virgilia, Mother Abbess|Mother Abbess]] * [[Laura Benanti]] as Elsa Schräder / Fräulein Schweiger * [[Christian Borle]] as [[Franz Wasner|Max Detweiler]] {{div col end}} ;Supporting {{Div col}} * [[Jessica Molaskey]] as Sister Berthe * [[Elena Shaddow]] as Sister Sophia * [[Christiane Noll]] as Sister Margaretta * [[Ariane Rinehart]] as [[Agathe von Trapp|Liesl von Trapp]] * Michael Nigro as [[Rupert von Trapp|Friedrich von Trapp]] * Ella Watts-Gorman as [[Maria Franziska von Trapp|Louisa von Trapp]] * Joe West as [[Werner von Trapp|Kurt von Trapp]] * [[Sophia Anne Caruso]] as [[Hedwig von Trapp|Brigitta von Trapp]] * Grace Rundhaug as [[Johanna von Trapp|Marta von Trapp]] * Peyton Ella as [[Martina von Trapp|Gretl von Trapp]] * Michael Campayno as Rolf * Sean Cullen as Franz * [[Kristine Nielsen]] as Frau Schmidt * C.J. Wislon as Herr Zeller * [[Michael Park (actor)|Michael Park]] as Baron Elberfeld * Paula Leggett Chase as Baroness Elberfeld and a nun * [[John Michael Bolger|John Bolger]] as Admiral von Scheiber {{div col end}} Benanti had previously portrayed Maria von Trapp on Broadway in 1998. [[Craig Zadan]] and [[Neil Meron]], who had previously worked with Borle on the NBC musical drama television series ''[[Smash (U.S. TV series)|Smash]]'', served as [[executive producer]]s.{{Cite web|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/459565/first-look-carrie-underwood-as-maria-in-the-sound-of-music|title=First Look: Carrie Underwood as Maria in The Sound of Music|first=Tierney|last=Bricker|work=''[[E!#E! Online|E! Online]]''|publisher=[[E!| E! Entertainment Television, LLC]]. A Division of [[NBCUniversal]]|date=September 16, 2013|accessdate=September 17, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nbc.com/sound-of-music/about//#credits?par=The%20Sound%20of%20Music%20Live!|title=The Sound of Music Live! - All Bios - Newest|work=''[[NBC|NBC.com]]''|publisher=[[NBCUniversal]]|accessdate=September 17, 2013}} Other credits include [[Rob Ashford]] and [[Beth McCarthy-Miller]] as [[Film director|directors]], Ashford also was the [[choreographer]], Priscilla Taussig served as [[Television producer|producer]], David Chase as [[music director]] and Derek McLane as [[production designer]]. [[Catherine Zuber]] was [[costume designer]] and Bernie Telsey was the [[casting director]]. The production is taken from the book by [[Howard Lindsay]] and [[Russel Crouse]] and is based off the [[memoir]], ''[[The Story of the Trapp Family Singers]]'' by Maria von Trapp.{{cite AV media notes|title=[[The Sound of Music: Music from the NBC Television Event]]|type=[[Compact disc]] [[liner notes]]|year=2013|publisher=[[Sony Masterworks|Masterworks]]|page=23|id=88843 79814 2}} ==Development and promotion== On June 30, 2012, NBC's chairman [[Robert Greenblatt|Bob Greenblatt]] announced the network's plans to broadcast a live adaptation of the Broadway musical ''[[The Sound of Music]]'' in 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/article/Breaking-News-NBC-Craig-ZadanNeil-Meron-to-Present-Live-Broadcast-of-THE-SOUND-OF-MUSIC-20120629#ixzz2CoUEezC5|title=NBC & Craig Zadan/Neil Meron to Present Live Broadcast of THE SOUND OF MUSIC!|author=BWW News Desk|date=June 30, 2012|work=''broadwayworld.com''|publisher=Wisdom Digital Media|accessdate=January 9, 2014}} On November 30, 2012, the network announced that [[country music]] and [[American Idol (season 4)|fourth season]] of ''[[American Idol]]'', winner performer Carrie Underwood would star as Maria von Trapp in the production. In a statement, Greenblatt justified Underwood's involvement, saying that "[Maria] was an iconic woman who will now be played by an iconic artist."{{cite web|title=Carrie Underwood to Star as Maria von Trapp on TV's The Sound of Music|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20652388,00.html|last=Silverman|first=Stephen M.|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|publisher=[[Time Inc.]]|date=November 30, 2012|accessdate=November 30, 2012}} On September 16, 2013, NBC revealed the full cast of the special, and released a promotional image depicting Underwood as Maria von Trapp, wearing blond braids and a [[dirndl]], referencing one of [[Julie Andrews]]' "most iconic moments" from the [[The Sound of Music (film)|film adaptation]].{{cite journal|last=Strecker|first=Erin|title=NBC to re-air 'Sound of Music Live!' on Saturday|journal=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|publisher=Time Inc.|date=December 10, 2013|url=http://insidetv.ew.com/2013/12/10/sound-of-music-live-encore/|accessdate=December 13, 2013}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/tv-movies/carrie-underwood-stars-maria-sound-music-live-poster-article-1.1458571|title=Carrie Underwood dons dirndl for NBC's 'The Sound of Music Live!' poster|first=Margaret|last=Eby|work=[[Daily News (New York)|New York Daily News]]|accessdate=September 17, 2013|date=September 17, 2013}} Prior to being cast, Underwood personally asked Andrews for her endorsement of the role and the production, stating that "whenever I do a cover of somebody's song or whatever, I always get permission of the artist first."{{cite web|url=http://www.entertainmentwise.com/news/134782/Carrie-Underwood-Reveals-Julie-Andrews-Gave-Sound-Of-Music-Live-TV-Special-Her-Seal-Of-Approval|title=Carrie Underwood Reveals Julie Andrews Gave 'Sound Of Music Live!' TV Special Her Seal Of Approval|last=McGrath|first=Rachel|date=December 5, 2013|accessdate=January 1, 2014|work=[[Gigwise|Entertainmentwise]]|publisher=[[Gigwise|Giant Digital]]}}{{cite web|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/487610/carrie-underwood-dishes-on-the-sound-of-music-live-and-how-she-got-julie-andrew-s-seal-of-approval-watch-now|title=Carrie Underwood Dishes on The Sound of Music Live! and How She Got Julie Andrew's Seal of Approval—Watch Now!|last=Aguilera|first=LeAnne|date=December 4, 2013|accessdate=January 1, 2013|work=[[E!#E! Online|E! Online]]|publisher=[[NBCUniversal]]}} Produced on a budget of around $9 million, ''The Sound of Music Live!'' was broadcast live from a soundstage built at Grumman Studios in [[Bethpage, New York]].{{cite web |url=http://www.newsday.com/entertainment/tv/carrie-underwood-s-sound-of-music-special-to-air-live-from-bethpage-1.6528060|title=Carrie Underwood's 'Sound of Music' special to air live from Bethpage|last1=Amodio|first1=Joseph|date=December 2, 2013|website=[[Newsday]]|publisher=[[Cablevision]]|accessdate=December 6, 2013}} NBC, as well as producers [[Craig Zadan]] and [[Neil Meron]], emphasized that the production was not a remake of the film, but an adaptation of the musical itself; Meron iterated that "the audience will discover, within the first few minutes of watching the show, that they are not seeing a TV version of the movie. They'll know right away it's ''The Sound of Music'', but it's a different ''Sound of Music'' than they are accustomed to seeing on film." Meron felt that if successful, the broadcast could "open the door to another kind of entertainment that can exist on TV." He also praised the involvement of Underwood as the star of the production, believing that she was a quick learner, and "has all of the qualities of Maria." Greenblatt was highly supportive of the project, as he was, in the words of Zadan, a "passionate devotee of theater". Zadan considered the production to be "one of the profoundly complicated, amazing experiences we’ve ever had", noting the additional challenges created by the live broadcast.{{cite web|title=‘Sound of Music Live’: Producers Call It a ‘Profoundly Complicated, Amazing Experience’|url=https://variety.com/2013/tv/news/sound-of-music-live-a-profoundly-complicated-amazing-experience-1200925997/|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|last=Littleton|first=Cynthia|date=December 6, 2013|accessdate=December 9, 2013}}{{cite web|title=NBC's 'Sound of Music' Producers on Live Show Fears and Big Expectations (Q&A)|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/nbcs-sound-music-producers-live-661941|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]| last=Ng|first=Philiana|date=December 5, 2013|accessdate=December 9, 2013}} Promoted by NBC as a "three-hour holiday event", ''The Sound of Music Live!'' was aired as part of a push by NBC to air more live entertainment specials. Among its most popular programs in recent years have been those with live components (such as ''[[The Voice (U.S. TV series)|The Voice]]'' and ''[[NBC Sunday Night Football|Sunday Night Football]]''); NBC's Jennifer Salke believed that the increased level of [[social networking service|social network]] interaction possible in a live broadcast, along with the feeling of being part of an "event", would encourage viewers to watch the special live instead of [[Video on-demand|on-demand]] or from a recording. NBC's previous attempt at event television, ''[[The Million Second Quiz]]'', was met with mixed reviews and viewership, but NBC did indicate that [[Subway (restaurant)|Subway]]'s advertising throughout the series brought a higher level of [[Brand awareness|awareness]] to the brand.{{cite web|title=NBC Plots Aggressive Live Programming Strategy|url=http://adage.com/article/media/nbc-plots-aggressive-live-programming-strategy/245473/|work=[[AdAge]]|publisher=[[Crain Communications]]|last=Poggi|first=Jeanine|date=December 2, 2013|accessdate=December 6, 2013}} The television special was also the first live musical special in almost fifty years on NBC.{{cite AV media notes|title=The Sound of Music: Music from the NBC Television Event|type=[[Compact disc]] [[liner notes]]|year=2013|publisher=[[Sony Masterworks|Masterworks]]|page=7|id=88843 79814 2}} Retail chain [[Walmart]] served as the presenting sponsor for ''The Sound of Music Live!''. NBC also produced five themed Walmart commercials to air throughout the special, featuring scenes of a family using products from the store set to songs from ''The Sound of Music''. The five ads were timed to air during the commercial break following the scene where the song was featured; NBC's advertising chief Dan Lovinger considered the ads to be a way to "enhance the excitement" of the presentation for families.{{cite web|title=Walmart Ads for NBC’s "Sound of Music" Will Sound Just Like the Show|url=https://variety.com/2013/tv/news/walmart-ads-for-nbcs-sound-of-music-will-sound-just-like-the-show-1200922060/|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Mountain" - Nuns * "End Credits" (instrumental) {{div col end}} ==Reception== ===Critical reception=== Prior to the broadcast, members of the real-life von Trapp family were critical of casting Underwood to play Maria, agreeing with the notion that she would be a good singer but a poor actor. They suggested that [[Anne Hathaway]], who played [[Fantine]] in the [[Les Misérables (2012 film)|2012 film adaptation]] of ''[[Les Misérables (musical)|Les Misérables]]'' for which she won the [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress]], would have been a better choice.{{cite web|last=Rothman|first=Michael|title=Who the Von Trapps Wish Could Replace Carrie Underwood in ‘The Sound of Music Live’|url=http://abcnews.go.com/blogs/entertainment/2013/12/who-the-von-trapps-wish-could-replace-carrie-underwood-in-the-sound-of-music-live/|work=[[ABC News]]|accessdate=December 6, 2013|date=December 5, 2013}} ''The Sound of Music Live!'' received mixed reviews from entertainment critics, commending the show for its scope and supporting cast while questioning Underwood's acting capabilities. Kevin Fallon of ''[[The Daily Beast]]'' wrote: "Naturally, Underwood sounded astounding, as alive as those damned hills, every time she was asked to stand on top of things and belt. But whether it was because of nerves or lack of experience, her acting was painfully lifeless and amateur throughout the first two thirds of the lengthy ordeal. The singer, it seems, is a proud graduate of the school of 'If I don't blink, they'll think I'm acting!'"{{cite web|title=‘Sound of Music Live!’ Review: The Hills Are Barely Alive| url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2013/12/06/sound-of-music-live-review-the-hills-are-barely-alive.html|work=[[The Daily Beast]]|publisher=[[The Newsweek Daily Beast Company]]|last=Fallon|first=Kevin|date=December 6, 2013|accessdate=December 6, 2013}} Verne Gay of ''[[Newsday]]'' liked Underwood's performance, commenting that not only could she sing, but "she is a luminous stage presence who had the guts to take on one of the most iconic roles of the stage or screen."{{Cite web|url = http://www.newsday.com/entertainment/columnists/verne-gay/sound-of-music-and-carrie-underwood-largely-a-success-1.6550556|title = 'Sound of Music' -- and Carrie Underwood -- largely a success|date = December 5, 2013|accessdate =December 6, 2013|work = [[Newsday]]|publisher=[[Cablevision]]|last = Gay|first = Verne}} Brian Lowry of ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' described the production "as lifeless as [its] alpine backdrops."{{cite web |title=TV Review: '' 'The Sound of Music Live!' '' |url=https://variety.com/2013/tv/reviews/the-sound-of-music-live-tv-review-nbc-1200915170/ |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|last=Lowry|first=Brian |date= December 5, 2013|accessdate=December 6, 2013}} Marc Bernardin of ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' commended the production's aesthetics but called it a "very expensive karaoke", and he wrote that Underwood "doesn’t acquit herself so well when it comes to the carrying the emotional weight of the production." He also panned Moyer, criticizing his vocal performance and describing "his attempt at conveying an emotional hollowness" as "mildly constipated" and "clenched." However, he lauded Benanti, Borle and McDonald's "strong" performances.{{Cite web|url = http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/sound-music-live-tv-review-663346|title = The Sound of Music Live!: TV Review|date =December 5, 2013|accessdate=December 6, 2013|work = [[The Hollywood Reporter]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|last = Bernardin|first = Marc}} ===Ratings=== 18.62 million viewers watched ''The Sound of Music Live!'', making it the most-watched program of the night. It had a 4.6 rating, 13 share in the 18–49 demographic, which led all networks.{{cite news |url= http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2013/12/06/thursday-final-ratings-the-big-bang-theory-once-upon-a-time-the-millers-greys-anatomy-scandal-adjusted-down/220522/ |title=Thursday Final Ratings: 'The Big Bang Theory' & 'The X Factor' Adjusted Up; 'Once Upon a Time in Wonderland', 'The Millers', 'Grey's Anatomy' & Scandal' Adjusted Down|last=Kondolojy|first=Amanda |date=December 6, 2013 |work=TV by the Numbers|accessdate=December 7, 2013}} It attracted NBC's largest non-sports Thursday audience since the [[Goodnight, Seattle|series finale]] of ''[[Frasier]]'' in 2004 (which averaged 22.6 million viewers),{{cite news |url=http://tvline.com/2013/12/06/sound-of-music-live-ratings-nbc/ |title=Ratings: NBC's Sound of Music Live! Does Something Very Good; Glee and Grey's Eye Lows |last=Mitovich|first=Matt Webb |date=December 6, 2013 |work=TVLine |accessdate=December 7, 2013}} and NBC's largest non-sports audience on any night since the [[2007 Golden Globe Awards]].{{cite news |url=http://www.newsday.com/entertainment/tv/tv-zone-1.811968/the-sound-of-music-live-ratings-18-5-million-viewers-1.6554021 |title='The Sound of Music Live!' ratings: 18.5 million viewers |last=Gay |first=Verne |work=[[Newsday]] |date=December 6, 2013|accessdate=December 7, 2013}} The special performed the best with women in the 25–54 demographic, reaching a household rating of 7.0 for that demographic during the primetime broadcast.{{cite news |url=https://variety.com/2013/tv/news/sound-of-music-ratings-sing-for-nbc-thursday-night-1200925968/ |title='Sound of Music' Ratings Sing for NBC Thursday Night |last=Weisman |first=Jon |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]] |date=December 6, 2013|accessdate=December 7, 2013}} It did particularly well in Oklahoma City, the capital of Underwood's home state, where it was watched by 28% of TV viewers.{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/tv/2013/12/06/sound-of-music-live-nbc-ratings/3890653/ |title='Sound of Music' was ratings high|last=Levin |first=Gary|work=[[USA Today]] |publisher=[[Gannett Company]] |date=December 6, 2013|accessdate=December 7, 2013}} At least 38.69 million viewers watched a portion of ''The Sound of Music Live!''. Factoring in DVR viewership over the week following the broadcast, the special was viewed by 21.84 million, with 3.1 million within the first three days.{{cite web|title=‘The Sound Of Music’ Continues To Echo Across The Ratings Landscape|url=http://www.deadline.com/2013/12/the-sound-of-music-continues-to-echo-across-the-ratings-landscape/|website=Deadline Hollywood|accessdate=24 December 2013}}{{cite web|title=Ratings for The Sound of Music Live! Swell to Nearly 22 Million with DVR Playback|url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/185818-Ratings-for-The-Sound-of-Music-Live-Swell-to-Nearly-22-Million-with-DVR-Playback|work=Playbill|accessdate=24 December 2013}}{{cite web|title=Live ‘Sound of Music’ Added 3 Million Delayed Viewers|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/12/11/business/media/live-sound-of-music-added-3-million-delayed-viewers.html|work=[[The New York Times]]|last=Carter|first=Bill|date=December 10, 2013|accessdate=December 11, 2013}} Following its original airing, an encore presentation of ''The Sound of Music Live!'' aired on December 14, 2013, attracting 3.1 million viewers. It notably displaced one of NBC's two traditional airings of the film ''[[It's a Wonderful Life]]'' (the other being on Christmas Eve), which was bumped ahead to December 20, 2013.{{cite journal|last=Friedlander|first=Whitney|title=NBC to Re-Air ‘The Sound of Music Live!’|journal=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=December 10, 2013|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|url=https://variety.com/2013/tv/news/nbc-sound-of-music-live-reair-1200941859/|accessdate=December 14, 2013}}{{cite journal|last=Strecker|first=Erin|title=NBC to re-air 'Sound of Music Live!' on Saturday|journal=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|publisher= Entertainment Weekly Inc|date=December 10, 2013|url=http://insidetv.ew.com/2013/12/10/sound-of-music-live-encore/|accessdate=December 13, 2013}}{{cite news|url=http://www.journalnow.com/news/ask_sam/article_251bd091-1888-5c87-86d8-8137dc17cedf.html|title=Ask Sam: 'It's a Wonderful Life' pre-empted by 'Sound of Music Live'|work=[[Winston-Salem Journal]]|publisher=[[Berkshire Hathaway|BH Media]]|date=December 20, 2013|accessdate=December 20, 2013}} NBC's Bob Greenblatt considered the production to be a success, and signed Meron and Zadan to produce another live musical for the 2014 holiday season. Greenblatt felt that there were enough recognizable, family-friendly musicals to make events like ''The Sound of Music Live!'' an annual tradition, and he indicated that NBC received e-mails and phone calls from various theatrical rightsholders, expressing interest in having their musicals adapted in a similar fashion, In January 2014, NBC announced that it would broadcast a live version of ''[[Peter Pan Live!|Peter Pan]]'' in December 2014, and at NBC's [[upfronts]] in May 2014, Greenblatt announced that NBC had also obtained rights to produce an adaptation of ''[[The Music Man]]'', although the network did not announce any timeframe for the production.{{cite web|title=NBC Says It Will Put On a Show, Again| (2009–10) | Misc = }} '''This Is It''' was a planned [[concert residency]] by [[Michael Jackson]] which was scheduled to begin in July 2009 and end September 29, 2009 with a second leg which was scheduled to run from January 2010 through March 2010 with a total of 50 shows.https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/michael-jacksons-this-is-it-tour-balloons-to-50-show-run-stretching-into-2010-20090312 Jackson announced This Is It at a press conference in the [[The O2 Arena|O2 Arena]], stating that it would be his final series of concerts in London. [[AEG Live]], the concert promoters, released a promotional video that took up an entire commercial break, setting a record for [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]]. Initially, only 10 concerts were announced, but following public demand, 40 more concerts were added. Ticket sales broke several records and Jackson's album sales increased following the announcement; AEG Live estimated that the first 10 dates alone would have earned Jackson approximately £50 million. In preparation for the concert series, Jackson had been collaborating with high-profile figures including fashion designer [[Christian Audigier]], choreographer [[Kenny Ortega]] and bodybuilder [[Lou Ferrigno]]. Prior to Jackson's death in 2009, Allgood Entertainment sued Jackson for $40 million, claiming that he had breached an exclusivity agreement with them by agreeing to the This Is It concerts; the case was dismissed. After Jackson's death, AEG Live offered either refunds to ticket holders or a special "souvenir" ticket designed by Jackson. The cancelled shows, record-breaking ticket sales{{cite web |first=Daniel|last=Kreps |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/rockdaily/index.php/2009/03/12/michael-jacksons-this-is-it-tour-balloons-to-50-show-run-stretching-into-2010/ |title=Michael Jackson’s "This Is It!" Tour Balloons to 50-Show Run Stretching Into 2010 |publisher=''Rolling Stone'' |date=March 12, 2009 |accessdate=March 24, 2009 }}{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/7941221.stm |agency=BBC News |title= Michael Jackson announces comeback gigs |publisher= ''[[BBC]]''|date=March 13, 2009 |accessdate= November 5, 2009 |last=BBC staff }}{{cite web |url= http://www.livedaily.com/news/18434.html |author= The Livedaily Staff |work= [[LiveDaily]] |title= Michael Jackson breaking records with 50-show run in London |date= March 9, 2009 |accessdate= November 5, 2009 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100209062136/http://livedaily.com/news/18434.html |archivedate= February 9, 2010 |df= mdy-all }} and potential for a world tour{{cite web |url= http://au.news.yahoo.com/a/-/entertainment/6405947/australia-part-of-planned-jackson-tour/ |title= Australia part of planned world tour |publisher=[[Yahoo! 7]] |date= October 30, 2009 |accessdate= November 5, 2009 |last=Australia |first=Yahoo }}{{cite web |url= http://www.mtv.com/movies/news/articles/1624853/20091027/story.jhtml?rsspartner=rssColdFusion |author= The MTV Staff |work= MTV |title= This Is It Director Kenny Ortega On Michael Jackson's Final Rehearsals |date= November 5, 2009 |accessdate= September 23, 2009}} led to This Is It being termed "the greatest concert[s] that never happened."{{cite web |first=IGN |last=Staff |url=http://movies.ign.com/articles/101/1016381p1.html|title=Michael Jackson’s "This Is It!" Tour Balloons to 50-Show Run Stretching Into 2010 |publisher=''IGN'' |date=August 20, 2009 |accessdate=November 5, 2009}}{{cite web |url=http://www.michaeljackson.com/ru/this-is-it|title=''Jackson's This Is It This Fall'' | publisher=[[Sony]] |date=August 20, 2009 |accessdate=November 5, 2009|first=Sony |last=Staff}} [[Columbia Pictures]] acquired the footage of the rehearsals and released a [[concert film]], ''[[Michael Jackson's This Is It]],'' accompanied by a [[Michael Jackson's This Is It (album)|compilation album of the same name]]. ==Promotion and significance== {{Wikinews|Michael Jackson to make last public concerts}} Jackson announced the first 10 performances during a press conference at the O2 Arena on March 5, 2009. As many as 7,000 fans and 350 reporters awaited Jackon's arrival, many donning Jackson-related clothing.{{cite web |url=http://www.mtv.co.uk/artists/michael-jackson/news/100481-jackson-set-to-announce-shows|title=Jackson set to announce shows|publisher=MTV|date=March 5, 2009|accessdate=March 5, 2009}} {{cite news |last= Akbar |first=Arifa |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/news/jacko-on-tour-this-will-be-the-final-curtain-call-i-love-you-i-love-you-all-1638497.html|title=Jacko on tour: 'This will be the final curtain call. I love you, I love you all' – News, Music |publisher=''[[The Independent]]''|date=March 6, 2009|accessdate=March 6, 2009 | location=London}} He commented at the conference, "I just wanted to say that these will be my final show performances in London. When I say this is it, it really means this is it", adding that it was his "final curtain call", although he may have just been referring to performing in London. Organizers touted the residency as, "dramatic shows [that] promise an explosive return with a band of the highest calibre, a state-of-the-art stage show and incredible surprise [[support act]]s".{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/celebritynews/4944927/Michael-Jackson-announces-comeback-gigs.html |title=Michael Jackson announces comeback gigs |publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]''|date=March 6, 2009|accessdate=March 6, 2009 |last= Khan|first=Urmee | location=London}} Hours before the press conference, promotional posters for the residency were displayed around London. Further promotion took up an entire [[commercial break]] period on [[ITV London]] during ''[[Dancing on Ice (Series 4)|Dancing on Ice]]'', the first time this has ever happened for a musical artist. The advert, which cost £1 million to air, was viewed by 11 million people. {{cite web |last=Griffin|first=Zoe |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/celebs/news/2009/03/04/michael-jackson-has-50-medical-tests-to-prove-he-can-manage-02-arena-dates-115875-21171604/|title=Michael Jackson has 50 medical tests to prove he can manage 02 Arena dates |publisher=''[[Daily Mirror]]''|date=March 5, 2009|accessdate=March 5, 2009}} {{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/7925388.stm|title= 'Final curtain call' for Jackson|publisher=BBC|date=March 5, 2009|accessdate=March 6, 2009|last=Youngs |first=Ian }} {{cite web|url=http://www.mediaweek.co.uk/News/MostEmailed/888126/Michael-Jackson-takes-entire-three-half-minute-ITV-ad-slot/ |title=Michael Jackson takes entire three and a half minute ITV ad slot |publisher=www.mediaweek.co.uk|date=March 6, 2009|accessdate=March 6, 2009|last=Barnett|first=Emma }}{{cite web|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/celebs/news/2009/03/09/michael-jackson-live-dates-ad-during-dancing-on-ice-seen-by-11m-fans-115875-21184002/|title=Michael Jackson live dates ad during Dancing On Ice seen by 11m fans|publisher=''Daily Mirror''|date=March 9, 2009|accessdate=March 9, 2009}} The shows, Jackson's first significant concert events since the [[Michael Jackson: 30th Anniversary Celebration]] in 2001, had been cited as one of the year's most important musical events,{{cite news|first=Rosie|last=Swash|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2009/mar/05/michael-jackson-o2-arena|title=Michael Jackson can't fail to sell out the O2 arena|publisher=''[[The Guardian]]''|date=March 5, 2009|accessdate=March 5, 2009 | location=London}} and as the greatest comeback in the history of pop.{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-1151504/Michael-Jackson-chooses-Londons-O2-arena-greatest-comeback-history.html|author=Simon Cable |work=[[Dailymail.co.uk]] |title=Michael Jackson chooses London's O2 arena for the 'greatest comeback in history'|date=November 5, 2009 |accessdate=February 21, 2009}}{{cite web |url=http://www.nme.com/news/michael-jackson/43249|title=Michael Jackson announces O2 Arena London gigs — and retirement?|publisher=''[[NME]]''|date=March 5, 2009|accessdate=March 5, 2009}} Randy Phillips, president and chief executive of [[AEG Live]], stated that the first 10 dates would earn Jackson approximately £50 million (about US$80.1 million).{{cite news|first=Patrick |last= Foster |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/article5854735.ece|title=Michael Jackson grand finale curtain-raiser|publisher=''[[The Times]]''|date=March 6, 2009|accessdate=March 5, 2009 | location=London}} ''[[The Guardian]]'' characterized the concerts as an "astonishing comeback for a man who in recent years has been dogged by controversy", adding that Jackson still had "enormous commercial clout". The ''[[Evening Standard]]'' stated that the deal was the "showbiz coup of the decade" for AEG Live, while ''[[The Independent]]'' remarked that the finalized 50 concerts would provide London with a "much-needed" economic boost.{{cite web |first=Amar |last=Singh |url=http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard/article-23661911-details/Detoxing+brand+Jacko/article.do |title=Detoxing Brand Jacko |publisher=''[[Evening Standard]]'' |date=March 13, 2009 |accessdate=March 24, 2009 }}{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/features/the-barometer-michael-jackson-angela-gheorghiu-horne-and-corden-madonna-in-fancy-dress-1649091.html |title=The Barometer: Michael Jackson; Angela Gheorghiu; Horne and Corden; Madonna in fancy dress |publisher=''The Independent'' |date=March 20, 2009 |accessdate=March 25, 2009 | location=London}} Joe Cohen, chief executive of [[Seatwave]], told [[BBC 6 Music]] that the shows would generate £1 billion for the economy.{{cite web |url=http://www.metro.co.uk/metrolife/music/article.html?Michael_Jackson_in_billion_pound_boost_to_economy&in_article_id=652877&in_page_id=25 |title=Michael Jackson in 'billion pound' boost to economy |publisher=''[[Metro (Associated Metro Limited)|Metro]]'' |date=May 8, 2009 |accessdate=June 12, 2009 }} ==Public interest== [[File:O2 with Canary Wharf and City of London (15007282651).jpg|right|thumb|250px|The O2 Arena, where the concerts would have been held]] Some websites offered early tickets, which the [[Association of Secondary Ticket Agents]] warned were fake. "We are warning people not to buy tickets that are not yet on sale because it is unlikely that they will receive those tickets", announced the organization's chief, Graham Burns. He concluded, "It's impossible when the dates haven't been announced to be selling tickets for something when there are no announced dates".{{cite web|url=http://www.nme.com/news/michael-jackson/43235|title=Michael Jackson London 02 Arena ticket warning issued|publisher=''NME''|date=March 5, 2009|accessdate=March 5, 2009}} Jackson's official website allowed fans to register early for a "pre-sale" draw. Some fans had difficulty applying, as the website could not deal with the large number of registrations—reportedly up to 16,000 applications a second.{{cite news |first=Matthew|last=Moore|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/celebritynews/4945911/Michael-Jackson-O2-ticket-website-attracting-16000-visits-a-second.html|title=Michael Jackson O2 ticket website attracting 16,000 visits a second |publisher=''The Daily Telegraph'' |date=March 6, 2009|accessdate=March 6, 2009 | location=London}} In the space of 24 hours, nearly a million people from around the world registered for pre-sale tickets, enough to fill the venue 50 times over.{{cite web |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/celebs/news/2009/03/06/michael-jackson-adds-10-more-dates-to-comeback-tour-115875-21177334/|title=Michael Jackson adds 10 more dates to comeback tour |publisher=''Daily Mirror'' |date=March 6, 2009|accessdate=March 6, 2009}}{{cite web |url=http://www.mtv.co.uk/artists/michael-jackson/news/102275-michael-jackson-announces-dates |title=Michael Jackson Announces Dates |publisher=MTV |date=March 10, 2009 |accessdate=March 29, 2009 }} Tickets that had not even been printed were selling on auction website [[eBay]] for £300.{{cite news|first=Elizabeth |last=Day |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2009/mar/08/michael-jackson-profile-pop-culture |title=Off the wall but still invincible |publisher=''The Guardian'' |date=March 8, 2009|accessdate=March 8, 2009 | location=London}} Sales of Jackson's albums increased following the press conference. Overnight, sales of ''[[Off the Wall]]'' rose 200%, ''[[Bad (album)|Bad]]'' rose 110%, ''[[Dangerous (Michael Jackson album)|Dangerous]]'' rose 165% and ''[[Thriller 25]]'' rose 155%.* {{cite web |url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/showbiz/music/article2302221.ece |title=Jacko's album sales are backo|date=March 7, 2009 |publisher=[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090310080317/http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/showbiz/music/article2302221.ece |archive-date=March 10, 2009 |dead-url=yes}} The two-day pre-sale began on March 11, and 40 extra dates were added to meet high demand—five of these dates were reserved in their entirety for the public sale. More than 1.5  million fans caused two sites offering pre-sale tickets to crash within minutes of going online.{{cite web |url=http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/showbiz/article-23660868-details/1.5m+fans+crash+sites+in+rush+for+Jacko+gig/article.do |title=1.5m fans crash sites in rush for Jacko gig |publisher=''Evening Standard'' |date=March 11, 2009 |accessdate=March 30, 2009 }} In the space of two hours, 190,000 tickets were sold.{{cite news |first=Simon |last=Cable |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-1161160/Fans-fury-touts-sell-Michael-Jackson-concert-tickets-16-000-pair-black-market.html |title=Fans' fury as touts sell Michael Jackson concert tickets for up to £16,000 a pair on black market |publisher=''Daily Mail'' |date=March 13, 2009 |accessdate=March 30, 2009 | location=London}} Two million people tried to buy pre-sale tickets in the space of 18 hours.{{cite news |first=David |last=Miranda |url=http://www.news.com.au/heraldsun/story/0,21985,25175199-5006024,00.html |title=Michael Jackson doubles London shows after 2 million seek tickets |publisher=''[[Herald Sun]]'' |date=March 12, 2009 |accessdate=April 1, 2009 }} Veronica Schmidt of ''[[The Times]]'' stated of the reception, "Michael Jackson has floored his critics",{{cite news |first=Veronica |last=Schmidt |url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/music/article5889522.ece |title=Michael Jackson sells out London concerts and adds more shows |publisher=''The Times'' |date=March 11, 2009 |accessdate=April 1, 2009 }} while organizers proclaimed it a "cultural phenomenon".{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7940515.stm |title=Jackson to play 50 gigs at the O2 |publisher=BBC |date=March 12, 2009 |accessdate=April 1, 2009 }} It was announced that Jackson would break the record for number of shows performed by an artist at a single venue, which had been set by [[Prince (musician)|Prince]], who hosted a residency at the same arena for his [[21 Nights in London: The Earth Tour]] concerts. According to Jackson's website, the following records were or would have been broken: "The biggest audience ever to see an artist in one city", "The greatest number of people to attend a series of arena shows", "The fastest ticket sales in history". Randy Phillips acknowledged that Jackson could have sold out even more dates, but this would have conflicted with other career plans.{{cite web |first=Ray |last=Waddell |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/269213/update-michael-jackson-up-to-50-london-shows |title=Update: Michael Jackson Up To 50 London Shows |publisher=''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' |date=March 12, 2009 |accessdate=April 1, 2009 }} On March 13, the other 50% of seats for dates 1–45 and all the seats for dates 46–50 went on sale to the general public. Within four hours, all 50 dates had sold out.* {{cite web |url=https://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/Showbiz-News/Michael-Jackson-This-Is-It-Shows-At-O2-Sell-Out-After-Tickets-Go-On-General-Sale/Article/200903215240762?lpos=Showbiz_News_First_Home_Article_Teaser_Region_1&lid=ARTICLE_15240762_Michael_Jackson_This_Is_It_Shows_At_O2_Sell_Out_After_Tickets_Go_On_General_Sale |title=Jackson's Tears Of Joy As O2 Shows Sell Out |date=March 13, 2009 |publisher=[[Sky News]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090316004206/https://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/Showbiz-News/Michael-Jackson-This-Is-It-Shows-At-O2-Sell-Out-After-Tickets-Go-On-General-Sale/Article/200903215240762?lpos=Showbiz_News_First_Home_Article_Teaser_Region_1&lid=ARTICLE_15240762_Michael_Jackson_This_Is_It_Shows_At_O2_Sell_Out_After_Tickets_Go_On_General_Sale |archive-date=March 16, 2009 |dead-url=yes}}} At this stage, the sales of ''[[King of Pop (album)|King of Pop]]'' were up 400% and the sales of ''[[Thriller (Michael Jackson album)|Thriller]]'' were up 200%.{{cite news |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2009/SHOWBIZ/Music/03/13/michael.jackson.concerts.tickets/ |title=750,000 tickets for Jackson concerts sell in 4 hours |publisher=CNN |date=March 13, 2009 |accessdate=April 1, 2009 }} Tickets appeared on eBay for as much as £10,000.{{cite news |first=Rosie |last=Swash |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2009/mar/13/michael-jackson-o2-arena-residency-sells-out |title=Michael Jackson's 50 dates at London's O2 arena sell out |publisher=''The Guardian'' |date=March 13, 2009 |accessdate=April 1, 2009 }} ==Preparation and concert details== The 50-concert run was originally scheduled to start on July 8, 2009 and conclude on February 24, 2010.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/8060282.stm |title=Jackson delays opening tour dates |publisher=BBC |date=May 20, 2009 |accessdate=June 12, 2009 }} Each of the shows would have been performed at the O2 Arena in London, which has a capacity of 23,000.{{cite web|first=Andre|last=Paine|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/269278/michael-jackson-says-london-concerts-to-be-final-curtain-call|title=Michael Jackson Says London Concerts To Be 'Final Curtain Call'|publisher=''Billboard''|date=March 5, 2009|accessdate=March 5, 2009}} New York-based fashion designer [[Zaldy]] served as head costumer, creating ten of Jackson's stage looks while the other six were created by his longtime costumers, Michael Bush and Dennis Tompkins. Jay Ruckel from La Crasia Gloves recreated Jackson's iconic single glove for the concerts.{{cite news |first=William |last=Sherman |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/money/2009/06/14/2009-06-14_theyre_still_proudly_making_it_in_nyc_manufacturing_alive__well_at_feisty_factor.html |title=Michael Jackson, Hubble Telescope draw from New York manufacturing |publisher=''[[New York Daily News]]'' |date=June 14, 2009|accessdate=June 20, 2009}} The costumes he was to wear during the shows were encrusted with 300,000 [[Swarovski crystals]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nme.com/news/michael-jackson/45530|title=Extra Michael Jackson O2 Arena tickets made available|date=June 23, 2009|publisher=NME|accessdate=June 26, 2009}} In April 2009, thousands of dancers flew in from all around the world to audition from the 13th to the 15th for Jackson, who helped select the 11 finalists in person.{{cite web |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/268649/michael-jackson-rehearsals-move-forward |title=Michael Jackson Rehearsals Move Forward |publisher=Billboard |date=May 12, 2009 |accessdate=June 12, 2009 }} [[Kenny Ortega]], who had collaborated with Jackson previously, was to work on the overall design and direction of concerts. Ortega said that the final product would have been a "theatrical musical experience".{{cite web |url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/Showbiz-News/Michael-Jackson-Auditions-Dancers-For-Tour-And-Works-With-Director/Article/200905215280285 |title=Michael Jackson Gets Ready For Tour |publisher=Sky News |date=May 12, 2009 |accessdate=June 12, 2009 }}{{cite web |url=http://www.nme.com/news/michael-jackson/44599 |title=Michael Jackson enlists 'High School Musical' director for London O2 shows |publisher=''NME'' |date=May 12, 2009 |accessdate=June 12, 2009 }}{{cite web |url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/Showbiz-News/Michael-Jacksons-Comeback-Tour-12-Dancers-Picked-To-Join-Singer-On-Stage-At-Londons-O2-Aena/Article/200905315284334 |title=This Is It: Jacko Picks Comeback Gig Dancers |publisher=Sky News |date=May 19, 2009 |accessdate=June 12, 2009 }} According to Randy Philips, £13 million was to be spent on producing the concerts, which would have included 18–22 songs and 22 different sets. There also would have been [[Aerial dance|aerial dancing]] similar to routines by [[Cirque du Soleil]]. Carla Ferrigno told [[Reuters]] that [[Lou Ferrigno|her husband Lou]] had been helping Jackson train in advance of the shows. Jackson and Ferrigno had previously worked together.{{cite news |first=Alex |last=Dobuzinskis |url=http://blogs.reuters.com/fanfare/2009/06/19/the-hulk-trains-michael-jackson-ahead-of-london-concerts/ |title=The Hulk trains Michael Jackson ahead of London concerts |publisher=Reuters |date=June 19, 2009 |accessdate=June 19, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090621224923/http://blogs.reuters.com/fanfare/2009/06/19/the-hulk-trains-michael-jackson-ahead-of-london-concerts/ |archivedate=June 21, 2009 |df=mdy-all }} On May 20, it was announced that the first concert would be pushed back five days to July 13 and three other July dates would be rescheduled for March 2010. AEG Live said that the delay was necessary because more time was needed for dress rehearsals. The revised schedule called for 27 shows between July 13 and September 29, 2009, followed by a three-month break, before resuming in the new year with 23 more shows between January 7 and March 6, 2010. Some fans petitioned for the reversal of AEG Live's decision.{{cite web |url=http://www.nme.com/news/michael-jackson/44820 |title=Michael Jackson fans launch petition over O2 Arena postponement |publisher=''NME'' |date=May 21, 2009 |accessdate=June 12, 2009 }} In late June, several hundred seats for each of the dates were put on sale. These seats were held back until production logistics were worked out.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/8115638.stm |title=More Jackson tickets up for sale |publisher=BBC |date=June 23, 2009 |accessdate=June 25, 2009 }} It was suggested that after the London concerts, Jackson might head to [[Australia]], [[Europe]], [[India]], [[China]], [[Hong Kong]] and [[Japan]] before moving on to North America. Randy Phillips, the CEO of [[AEG Live]], told The LA Times that Australia was part of Michael Jackson's international tour plans.{{cite web |url=http://www.take40.com/news/16590/michael-jackson-planning-australian-tour-before-his-death |title=Michael Jackson Planning Australian Tour Before His Death |publisher=Take 40 |date=June 28, 2009 |accessdate=May 6, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140504000236/http://www.take40.com/news/16590/michael-jackson-planning-australian-tour-before-his-death |archivedate=May 4, 2014 |df=mdy-all }} According to Jermaine Jackson's 2011 book ''You Are Not Alone: Michael Through a Brother's Eyes'', after the London concerts were finished, Jackson was planning to extend his deal with AEG Live which included new music, a potential three-picture movie deal, a series of one-off concert dates starting in China, a halftime slot at one of the future [[Super Bowl]] games to surpass his own halftime show at the [[Super Bowl XXVII]] in January 1993 and two more tours (one of which was to be a final reunion with his brothers based on a promise made to their [[Katherine Jackson|mother]] to see her sons perform together one last time before she passed away). After the deal was completed, he planned to take time off from musical entertainment and move on to (possibly) directing his own film ideas, such as making a feature-length motion picture based on his 1982 song "Thriller" and [[Michael Jackson's Thriller (music video)|the music video of the same name]]. It was also later revealed that [http://www.damienshields.com/michael-jacksons-halloween-special-that-never-was/ a yearly Halloween television special] based on his horror-themed songs, such as "Thriller" and "Ghosts", was part of Jackson's deal with AEG Live. In [[Trial of Conrad Murray|Conrad Murray's manslaughter trial]], David Walgren stated another one of Jackson's future plans was to open a children's hospital. This was heard in an audio tape Conrad Murray played of Jackson under the influence of propofol on May 10, 2009. His voice is barely recognisable in the recording, but he can be clearly heard saying that he wanted to build the greatest children's hospital in the world and name it after himself: The ''Michael Jackson's Children's Hospital''. Walgren also stated that while the tour was happening, Jackson wanted to buy an estate with streams, horses and animals so his three children, Prince, Paris and Blanket could live normal lives as their father performed the concerts, as he was photographed looking for a house in the United Kingdom with his children. Walgren also said that the tour would begin that summer, and Jackson could take his children out of school and bring them with him so they could see him perform in London. ===Songs prepared=== As shown in ''[[Michael Jackson's This Is It]]'', songs prepared for the concerts included "[[Wanna Be Startin' Somethin']]", "[[Jam (song)|Jam]]", "[[They Don't Care About Us]]", "[[Human Nature (Michael Jackson song)|Human Nature]]", "[[Smooth Criminal]]", "[[The Way You Make Me Feel]]", a medley of songs by [[The Jackson 5]] consisting of "[[I Want You Back]]", "[[The Love You Save]]", "[[I'll Be There (The Jackson 5 song)|I'll Be There]]" and "[[Shake Your Body (Down to the Ground)]]", "[[I Just Can't Stop Loving You]]", "[[Thriller (song)|Thriller]]", "[[Beat It]]", "[[Black or White]]", "[[Earth Song]]", "[[Billie Jean]]", and "[[Man in the Mirror]]". Later on, "[[Stranger in Moscow]]", "[[You Are Not Alone]]", "[[Don't Stop 'Til You Get Enough]]", "[[Rock with You (Michael Jackson song)|Rock with You]]", "[[Dirty Diana]]" ,"[[You Rock My World]]", "[[Dangerous (Michael Jackson song)|Dangerous]]", "[[We Are the World]]", "[[Heal the World]]" and "[[Will You Be There]]" were also confirmed to have been planned for the shows. Due to the larger than usual roster of songs, as well as time constraints, Jackson would perform some songs with one verse less than he did in previous tours (such as "Wanna Be Startin' Somethin'", "Jam", "The Way You Make Me Feel" and "Black or White"). "[[Bad (Michael Jackson song)|Bad]]" was rumored to have been reserved for select concerts. On the final dates, Jackson wanted to perform a ballad called "River Ripple", written by him, with an African choir and his children. During the final concert before "Man in the Mirror", Michael was slated to premiere a song called "Best of Joy", written and recorded in 2009 prior to Jackson's death. As of 2018, the full version of "River Ripple" remains unreleased (although snippets of the song have leaked on YouTube), while "Best of Joy" was officially released in 2010 on Jackson's first posthumous album of unreleased songs, ''[[Michael (album)|Michael]]''. ==Dates== {|class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" ! style="width:130px;"| Date ! style="width:130px;"| City ! Timor Dance) {{col-3}} ;Production and other personnel *[[Kenny Ortega]] – show direction *Alif Sankey – [[Assistant producer|associate production]] *Michael Cotten – [[Production designer|production design]] *Michael Curry – production design *Michael Jackson & [[Travis Payne]] – [[choreography]] *Stacy Walker – choreography assistance *Tony Testa – choreography assistance *Patrick Woodroffe – [[Lighting designer|lighting design]] *[[David Elsewhere]] – dance coaching *Shahzad Perez - Specialty Act *Gregg Smith – [[Casting (performing arts)|casting direction]] *Karen Faye Heinze – hair and make-up *[[Zaldy Goco]] – [[Costume designer|chief of costume design]] *Michael Bush – [[Costume designer|costume design]] *Dennis Thompkins - [[Costume designer|costume design]] *[[AEG Live]] – [[Promoter (entertainment)|promotion]] *Dave Polich - synth programming {{col-end}} ==Litigation== In June 2009, concert promoter Allgood Entertainment, represented by Ira Meyerowitz and Jon Kekielek of MJlawfirm, sued Jackson for $40 million. He claimed that Jackson, through his manager [[Frank DiLeo]], had agreed to a single and a $30 million reunion concert with [[The Jackson 5]] and his sister [[Janet Jackson]]. According to the concert promoter, the alleged contractual agreement prevented Jackson from performing elsewhere before the reunion concert and for a three-month period after it. Thus, agreeing to a 50 date residency at the O2 arena was an alleged breach of the Allgood Entertainment contract. The filing company stated that AEG Live knew of the alleged agreement with Jackson and used their dominance in the industry to coerce Jackson into agreeing to the residency.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/8094537.stm |title=Jackson sued over reunion concert |publisher=BBC |date=June 11, 2009 |accessdate=June 12, 2009 }}{{cite news |first=Sean |last=Michaels |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2009/jun/12/michael-jackson-sued-o2-arena|title=Michael Jackson sued for O2 arena residency|publisher=''The Guardian'' |date=June 12, 2009 |accessdate=June 12, 2009 | location=London}}{{cite news |first=Sean |last=Michaels |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2009/may/12/michael-jackson-comeback-concerts |title=Michael Jackson comeback concerts in jeopardy? |publisher=''The Guardian'' |date=June 12, 2009 |accessdate=June 12, 2009 | location=London}} In August 2010, the judge dismissed the case, stating that there was no evidence of a binding agreement, no contracts were signed.{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-11038050 | work=BBC News | title=Judge dismisses Jackson reunion claim | date=August 20, 2010}} The case was in limbo as of 2013.{{cite web|url=http://archive.recapthelaw.org/nysd/347380/ |title=AllGood Entertainment, Inc. et al v. Jackson et al (nysd/347380) – The RECAP Archive |publisher=Archive.recapthelaw.org |date= |accessdate=May 6, 2013}}{{cite web|author=Yazmeen |url=http://muzikfactorytwo.blogspot.com/2011/05/interview-with-patrick-allocco.html |title=Interview with Patrick Allocco- President of AllGood Entertainment ~ LET'S CALL SPADE A SPADE |publisher=Muzikfactorytwo.blogspot.com |date=May 24, 2011 |accessdate=May 6, 2013}} ==Jackson's death and refunds== {{Further|Death of Michael Jackson}} On June 25, 2009, Jackson died after going into [[cardiac arrest]] which was caused by an overdose of [[Propofol]] and [[Benzodiazepine|benzodiazepines]], eighteen days before his planned first show. AEG Live, who persuaded Jackson to sign up for the shows, faced a liability of up to £300 million and an empty venue for the next nine months.{{cite news|last=Sherwin|first=Adam|title=O2 arena counts cost as curtain closes on the greatest show of all|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/article6580748.ece|publisher=The Times|date=June 26, 2009|accessdate=June 26, 2009 | location=London}} The O2 arena stated that full refunds, including all ticket service charges, would be available to those who purchased tickets through authorized agents, but that "fans will have the option to be sent the actual tickets they would have received to attend the shows in lieu of the full refunds which are being offered."{{cite web |title=UCLA Statement — Michael Jackson|url=http://www.theo2.co.uk/inside/ucla-statement-michael-jackson.html |publisher=[[The O2 Arena]] |accessdate=July 1, 2009}} Fans who bought their tickets from private sellers potentially faced difficulties. eBay recommended that purchasers contact their sellers for refunds and stated that those who used PayPal can get their money back if the purchase was made during the last 45 days,{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/8120412.stm |title=Refund issues over Jackson gigs |publisher=''BBC News'' |date=June 26, 2009 |accessdate=June 26, 2009}} then later stated that "all buyers on the site will receive a full refund for their ticket purchase".{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/8122580.stm |title=eBay will refund Jackson tickets |publisher=BBC News |date=June 27, 2009 |accessdate=June 27, 2009}} ==Posthumous film and album== {{Further|Michael Jackson's This Is It|Michael Jackson's This Is It (album)}} Following Jackson's death, AEG stated that they had over "100 hours of footage of preparations and rehearsals for the shows".{{cite news |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/32360110 |title=Judge OKs Jackson performance film deal |agency=Associated Press |work=[[MSNBC|MSNBC.com]] |date=August 10, 2009 |accessdate=October 2, 2009}} On August 10, 2009, Los Angeles Superior Court Judge Mitchell Beckloff approved a deal between film distributor [[Columbia Pictures]] and AEG Live for the former company to purchase and distribute rehearsal footage of Jackson for a film entitled ''[[Michael Jackson's This Is It]]''.{{cite web |url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/showbiz/2009-08/06/content_8532737.htm |title=Michael Jackson film deal outlined in court papers |work=ChinaDaily.com |date=August 6, 2009 |accessdate=October 2, 2009}}{{cite news |url=http://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-ct-jackson11-2009aug11,0,2938755.story |author=Christopher Smith |work=[[LA Times|LA Times.com]] |title=Sony Pictures to produce Michael Jackson film |accessdate=September 21, 2009 | date=August 11, 2009}} According to court documents, Columbia paid $60 million (£35 million) for rights to the rehearsal footage.{{cite web |url=http://www.uncut.co.uk/news/michael_jackson/news/13441 |title=Michael jackson This Is It film deal agreed |work=Uncut.co.uk |date=August 8, 2009|accessdate=October 3, 2009}} The papers filed in court had reportedly stated that Jackson's estate will get 90% of the profits and that AEG Live will get the remaining 10% from the film's revenue.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2009/aug/11/michael-jackson-film-october-release |author=Rosie Swash |title=Michael Jackson film gets October release date |work=[[Guardian.co.uk]] |date=August 11, 2009 |accessdate=October 2, 2009 | location=London}} The film was directed by [[Kenny Ortega]] who was also the director of the live concert. It was compiled mostly from footage that was shot as reference for production discussions and was never meant to be shown publicly. Some of the music and vocals in the film were added from previous recordings, though most were from the live performance. The film was released on October 28, 2009.{{cite web |url=http://www.sonypictures.com/movies/michaeljacksonthisisit/international/ |title=This Is It Worldwide Release Dates |work=[[Sony Pictures|Sony Pictures.com]] |accessdate=September 21, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090922214515/http://www.sonypictures.com/movies/michaeljacksonthisisit/international/ |archivedate=September 22, 2009 |df=mdy-all }} An accompanying album to the film was also released. Titled ''[[Michael Jackson's This Is It (album)|This Is It]]'', the compilation was distributed internationally on October 26, and to North America the following day. The two-disc album features music "inspired from the documentary of the same name".{{cite news |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/music_blog/2009/09/the-michael-jackson-new-musical-onslaught-begins.html |author=Chris Lee |title=The Michael Jackson new-music onslaught begins [Updated] |work=[[The LA Times|TheLATimes.com]] |date=September 23, 2009 |accessdate=September 24, 2009}} Of the album, Sony said, "Disc one will feature the original album masters of some of Michael's biggest hits arranged in the same sequence as they appear in the film" and stated that "the disc ends with two versions of the 'never-released' '[[This Is It (Michael Jackson song)|This Is It]]' [...] This song is featured in the film's closing sequence and includes backing vocals by Michael's brothers, [[The Jacksons]] and Alvin Chea of Take 6."{{cite web |url=http://www.digitalspy.com/music/a178845/new-jackson-single-lp-to-be-released.html?imdb |title=New Jackson single, LP to be released |author=Tim Parks |date=September 23, 2009 |work=[[Digital Spy|Digital Spy.com]] |accessdate=September 24, 2009}} Sony added that the second disc will feature previously unreleased versions from Jackson's "catalogue of hits", along with a spoken word [[poem]] entitled "Planet Earth" and a 36-page commemorative booklet with "exclusive photos of Michael from his last rehearsal".{{cite web |url=http://www.theinsider.com/news/2870440_Unreleased_Michael_Jackson_Song_to_be_Revealed|author=The Insider Staff |work=[[The Insider (TV series)|TheInsider.com]] |title=Unreleased Michael Jackson Song to be Revealed |date=September 23, 2009 |accessdate=September 23, 2009}} ==See also== * [[Death of Michael Jackson]] * [[List of works published posthumously]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
